settings.title: Electric Scooter Troubleshooting
settings.subtitle: Select your scooter and tap an error code to see what it means and what to try next.
settings.panel_kaiju_sub: Tap an error to view the description and what to try.
settings.panel_aurora_sub: Tap an error to view the description and what to try.
settings.panel_edgerunner_sub: These codes are from the Edgerunner settings-menu controller/display.
settings.data_kaiju:
## Communication
bA|Rear Drive Communication Failure|Controller not communicating with rear drive|Communication|The controller cannot communicate with the rear drive.|Check integrity of the communication cable; Inspect for broken or damaged wires; Reseat connectors; Check for bent pins
FA|Front Drive Communication Failure|Controller not communicating with front drive|Communication|The controller cannot communicate with the front drive.|Check wiring for broken connections; Inspect connectors; Check for corrosion or damaged pins

## Throttle / Hall Sensor
b|Acceleration Finger Throttle Failure|Throttle signal abnormal|Throttle|The finger throttle is not sending a valid signal.|Replace the finger throttle
FC|Front Motor Hall Failure|Front motor hall sensor communication failure|Hall Sensor|The controller cannot read front motor hall signals.|Inspect motor hall wiring; If no wiring issues are found, replace the motor
bC|Rear Motor Hall Failure|Rear motor hall sensor communication failure|Hall Sensor|The controller cannot read rear motor hall signals.|Inspect motor hall wiring; If no wiring issues are found, replace the motor

## Battery / Voltage
E|Under-Voltage Alarm|Battery voltage too low|Battery|The controller detects low battery voltage and enters protection mode.|Check battery voltage; Fully charge the battery; Test again; If battery voltage is normal but the error persists, replace the controller

## Controller
FF|Front Controller Overcurrent Alarm|Front controller overcurrent detected|Controller|The front controller detected excessive current or possible MOSFET short.|Power off the scooter; Restart after 30–60 seconds; If the error persists, replace the controller
bF|Rear Controller Overcurrent Alarm|Rear controller overcurrent detected|Controller|High-speed riding or sudden obstacles caused high resistance, triggering protection mode.|Restart the scooter; Rotate the motor manually to reset; Avoid riding if the error returns
dF|Dual Controller Overcurrent Alarm|Both controllers overcurrent detected|Controller|Both controllers detected abnormal current draw.|Restart the scooter; If unresolved, inspect or replace both controllers

## Brake
H|Brake Failure|Brake signal abnormal|Brake|The brake handle hall switch is not properly closed.|Check the brake handle hall switch; If no fault is found, replace the brake handle

## Drive Starting Current
bL|Rear Drive Starting Current Abnormality|Rear drive startup current abnormal|Drive Current|Rear drive draws abnormal current during startup.|Remove and reinstall the rear drive battery; Restart the scooter; Replace the rear controller if unresolved
FL|Front Drive Starting Current Abnormality|Front drive startup current abnormal|Drive Current|Front drive draws abnormal current during startup.|Remove and reinstall the front drive battery; Restart the scooter; Replace the front controller if unresolved

## Motor Blocking
Fd|Front Motor Blocking Alarm|Front motor blocked or stalled|Motor|The front motor is mechanically blocked or overloaded.|Push the motor to reset; Replace the controller or motor if the issue persists
bd|Rear Motor Blocking Alarm|Rear motor blocked or stalled|Motor|The rear motor is mechanically blocked or overloaded.|Push the motor to reset; Replace components if necessary
dd|Front & Rear Motor Blocking Alarm|Both motors blocked|Motor|Both motors detected a blocking condition.|Inspect both motors and controllers; Follow standard motor blocking troubleshooting steps
settings.data_aurora:
## Communication
A|Communication Failure|Display/controller not talking to controller|Communication|The scooter detects a fault on the main communication line.|Inspect the integrity of the communication line wiring; Check wiring between display and controller; Reseat connectors; Check for loose plugs or moisture

## Throttle
b|Acceleration Dial Failure|Finger throttle fault|Throttle|The throttle signal is abnormal or out of range.|Check throttle connector and wiring; Ensure plugs are fully seated; Replace the finger throttle if necessary

## Motor Hall
C|Motor Hall Failure|Motor hall communication failure|Hall Sensor|The controller cannot read the motor hall sensor signals.|Check the integrity of the motor hall communication wiring; If no abnormalities are found, replace the motor

## Battery / Voltage
E / E0|Undervoltage Alarm|Battery voltage too low|Battery|Battery voltage is below the safe operating threshold and protection is active.|Check if battery voltage is low; Fully charge the battery and test again; Test with another battery if available; If battery power is normal and the error persists, replace the controller

## Controller
F / F0|Overcurrent Alarm|Controller overcurrent detected|Controller|The controller detected excessive current, possibly due to an internal MOSFET short or high resistance load.|Power off the scooter and restart; If the issue persists after shutdown, replace the controller; During high-speed riding, potholes or stalls may trigger protection mode, which clears after shutdown and restart
settings.data_edgerunner:
## System Status
E00|Normal Status|System operating normally|System|No faults detected and the system is operating as expected.|No action required

## Battery / Voltage
E06|Battery Undervoltage|Battery voltage too low|Battery|Battery voltage has dropped below the safe operating threshold.|Fully charge the battery; Test again after charging; Replace battery if the issue persists

## Motor Hall
E07|Motor Hall Fault|Motor hall sensor communication failure|Hall Sensor|The controller cannot correctly read the motor hall sensor signals.|Check motor hall communication wiring; Inspect connectors; Replace the motor if no wiring issues are found

## Throttle
E08|Transfer Handle Malfunction|Throttle or transfer handle fault|Throttle|The throttle/transfer handle is not sending a valid signal.|Check throttle wiring and connector; Reseat plugs; Replace the throttle if necessary

## Controller
E09|Overcurrent Protection / Controller Malfunction|Controller overcurrent or internal fault|Controller|The controller detected excessive current or an internal malfunction.|Power off and restart the scooter; If the error persists, replace the controller

## Communication
E10|Controller Signal Not Received|Instrument did not receive controller signal|Communication|The display/instrument is not receiving data from the controller.|Check communication wiring between instrument and controller; Reseat connectors; Inspect for damaged wiring
E11|Instrument Signal Not Received|Controller did not receive instrument signal|Communication|The controller is not receiving data from the display/instrument.|Check communication wiring between controller and instrument; Reseat connectors; Inspect for loose or damaged plugs
settings.footer_note: Still stuck? If the error persists after trying these steps, stop riding and contact our support team so we can help or arrange a repair.

settings.liquid:
Electric Scooter Troubleshooting

Select your scooter below and tap an error code to see what it means and the steps to fix it. If you're unsure at any point, contact our support team.

Kaiju: Error Codes & Solutions

A – Communication Failures

Description

The display/controller is not communicating properly with the rear drive.

What to try

  • Inspect the communication cable between the main controller and rear drive.
  • Look for loose plugs, bent pins or damaged sections of wiring.
  • Reseat all connectors and test again.

Description

The display/controller is not communicating properly with the front drive.

What to try

  • Check communication wiring from the controller to the front drive.
  • Inspect for broken wires, cuts or corrosion in connectors.
  • Reseat connectors and test again.
B – Throttle & Hall Sensor Issues

Description

The scooter detects a fault with the finger throttle.

What to try

  • Check the throttle connector and wiring for damage or looseness.
  • If the wiring is fine, the throttle assembly will need to be replaced.

Description

The controller isn’t receiving correct Hall sensor signals from the front motor.

What to try

  • Inspect the Hall sensor wiring between the front motor and controller.
  • Look for cuts, crushed sections or loose connectors.
  • If wiring looks fine and the error persists, the front motor likely needs replacement.

Description

The controller isn’t receiving correct Hall sensor signals from the rear motor.

What to try

  • Inspect the Hall sensor wiring between the rear motor and controller.
  • Check connectors for moisture, corrosion or physical damage.
  • If no wiring issues are found and the error remains, the rear motor likely needs replacement.
E – Battery & Voltage Issues

Description

The controller detects low battery voltage and limits or stops output to protect the pack.

What to try

  • Charge the scooter fully, then test again.
  • If possible, test with a known fully charged battery.
  • If voltage is normal but the error remains, the controller may be faulty and require replacement.
F – Controller Overcurrent Issues

Description

The front controller has detected excessive current, often due to internal component failure.

What to try

  • Switch the scooter off completely and wait 30–60 seconds.
  • Restart and check if the error clears.
  • If the error stays, the front controller likely needs replacement.

Description

This can occur during high-speed riding over potholes, sudden obstacles or when the wheel is heavily jammed.

What to try

  • Turn the scooter off, then back on.
  • Gently spin the rear wheel by hand to ensure it turns freely.
  • If the error returns repeatedly, the rear controller and motor should be inspected or replaced.

Description

Both controllers are seeing overcurrent, often due to severe resistance or internal faults.

What to try

  • Power cycle the scooter and see if the error clears.
  • Inspect both motors for binding or mechanical obstruction.
  • If the issue continues, both controllers should be checked and may require replacement.
H – Brake Failure

Description

The controller reads the brake signal as constantly on or invalid.

What to try

  • Check that the brake lever returns fully and isn’t stuck.
  • Inspect the brake handle Hall switch and wiring for damage or loose connections.
  • If no obvious wiring issue is found, the brake handle assembly should be replaced.
L – Drive Starting Current Abnormalities

Description

The controller detects abnormal current when the rear drive starts.

What to try

  • Remove the rear drive battery and reinsert it securely.
  • Restart the scooter and test.
  • If the problem persists, the rear drive controller may need replacement.

Description

The controller detects abnormal current when the front drive starts.

What to try

  • Remove the front drive battery and reinsert it securely.
  • Restart the scooter and test.
  • If the problem persists, the front drive controller may need replacement.
D – Motor Blocking Issues

Description

The front motor is not rotating as expected (mechanically blocked or electronically locked).

What to try

  • With the scooter off, try pushing the front wheel gently to ensure it can rotate.
  • Check for foreign objects, rubbing brake pads or a bent rotor.
  • If nothing is visibly obstructing the wheel, the controller or motor may need replacement.

Description

The rear motor is not rotating as expected (mechanically blocked or electronically locked).

What to try

  • With the scooter off, try pushing the rear wheel gently to ensure it can rotate.
  • Check for debris, rubbing brakes or a bent rotor.
  • If there is no mechanical obstruction, the rear controller or motor may require replacement.

Description

Both motors show blocking behaviour, either mechanically or via the controllers.

What to try

  • Inspect both wheels for physical obstruction, brake drag or damage.
  • Switch the scooter off and on, then test carefully.
  • If the alarm is still present, both controllers and motors should be inspected by a technician.

Aurora: Error Codes & Solutions

A – Communication Failure

Description

The scooter detects a fault on the main communication line.

What to try

  • Inspect the communication line wiring between display and controller.
  • Check for loose plugs, damaged cables or moisture in connectors.
B – Acceleration Dial Failure

Description

The throttle signal is not within the expected range.

What to try

  • Check the throttle wiring and connector.
  • If wiring is OK, the finger throttle assembly needs replacement.
C or C0 – Motor Hall Failure

Description

The controller is not receiving correct Hall sensor signals from the motor.

What to try

  • Inspect the Hall communication line wiring between motor and controller.
  • If there are no visible wiring issues and the error persists, the motor will need replacement.
E or E0 – Undervoltage Alarm

Description

The controller has detected low battery voltage and is protecting the system.

What to try

  • Fully charge the scooter and test again.
  • If available, test with a different battery that has sufficient power.
  • If battery power is normal but the alarm remains, the controller may be faulty and require replacement.
F or F0 – Overcurrent Alarm

Description

The controller has detected excessive current. This may be caused by internal MOSFET breakdown or by very high resistance (e.g. hitting potholes or obstacles at speed).

What to try

  • Turn the scooter off completely and wait 30–60 seconds.
  • Turn it back on and see if the alarm clears.
  • If the alarm returns immediately, the controller likely needs inspection and replacement.

Still stuck? If the error persists after trying these steps, stop riding the scooter and get in touch so our team can help or arrange a repair.

Kaiju: Error Codes & Solutions

Error Code Description Solution
A - Communication Failures
bA Rear Drive Communication Failure Check the integrity of the communication cable wiring or inspect for broken wires.
FA Front Drive Communication Failure Check for wiring issues or broken connections.
B - Throttle & Hall Sensor Issues
b Acceleration Finger Throttle Failure Replace the finger throttle.
FC Front Motor Hall Failure Inspect the motor hall communication wiring. If no issues are found, replace the motor.
bC Rear Motor Hall Failure Same as front motor hall failure – check wiring first, then replace the motor if necessary.
E - Battery & Voltage Issues
E Under-Voltage Alarm Check if the battery voltage is low.
Charge the battery and test it.
Try using a fully charged battery.
If the battery power is normal but the error persists, replace the controller.
F - Controller Overcurrent Issues
FF Front Drive Controller Overcurrent Alarm The controller’s internal MOS tube may have short-circuited. If the error remains after shutting down, replace the controller.
bF Rear Controller Overcurrent Alarm This can happen during high-speed riding over potholes or sudden obstacles, causing high resistance and triggering protection mode. Restart the motor or rotate it manually to reset.
dF Dual Controller Overcurrent Alarm Same as above—try resetting; if the issue persists, inspect or replace controllers.
H - Brake Failure
H Brake Failure Check if the brake handle Hall switch is properly closed. If no issue is found, replace the brake handle.
L - Drive Starting Current Abnormalities
bL Rear Drive Starting Current Abnormality Remove and reinsert the rear drive battery, then restart. If the issue persists, replace the rear drive controller.
FL Front Drive Starting Current Abnormality Remove and reinsert the front drive battery, then restart. If unresolved, replace the front drive controller.
D - Motor Blocking Issues
Fd Front Motor Blocking Alarm Try pushing the motor to reset. If the issue persists, replace the controller or motor.
bd Rear Motor Blocking Alarm Same as front motor blocking—push to reset, then replace if necessary.
dd Front & Rear Motor Blocking Alarm Check both motors and controllers for issues, following the same troubleshooting steps.

Aurora: Error Codes & Solutions

Error Code Description Solution
A - Communication Failure
A Communication Failure Check the integrity of the communication line wiring.
B - Acceleration Dial Failure
b Acceleration Dial Failure Replace the finger throttle.
C or C0 - Motor Hall Failure
C Motor Hall Failure Check the integrity of the motor Hall communication line wiring. If no abnormalities are found, replace the motor.
E or E0 - Undervoltage Alarm
E Undervoltage Alarm Check if the battery voltage is low. Charge the battery and test it. Alternatively, replace with a battery that has sufficient power for testing. If the battery power is normal, replace the controller and test.
F or F0 - Overcurrent Alarm
F Overcurrent Alarm The internal MOS tube of the controller may have broken down, causing a short circuit. If the issue persists after shutting down, replace the controller. During high-speed riding, if you encounter potholes or stalls, the motor may experience strong resistance, triggering a large reverse current that activates protection mode. This will disappear after shutdown and restart.
